description: BEWARE, if you ever place a large order for a party, your food will NOT be ready at the requested time, I just came in for a 5p pickup and was told at first they could not find my order and then once they did, it would not be ready for 25 minutes, very disappointing!
author: Sabina N.

description:
The food was delicious and the service was superb. The only reason I awarded four stars is because the meat and cheese pupusas had very little meat inside. However, everything else that we ordered was very good. 

The location is small but cozy, and keep pretty clean.

I will definitely visit again.
author: Osmin F.

description: love this place - very casual, yummy pupusas made by these adorable women behind the counter.  Great place to bring kids.
author: Mike N.

description:
#30 on the 2011 7x7 List: Pupusas
#32 on the 2009 7x7 List: Pupusas

-Tasty?  Cheap, clean-lookin' and incredibly not greasy!

-Service:  Very prompt and friendly.  The five of us each ordered one pupusa (under $3) for lunch (we were full from breakfast) and they let us sit here for about an hour and a half.

-Ambiance:  like any ol' cafe; clean; spacious; only a few tables though; bar seating is available.

-Worth the trip/try?  Yes - and while you are here in Bernal Heights, you might want to check out some other food items on the 7x7 list in the area since it's a little bit of a trek from the center of the city.  We were just too full at this point to do so.

We had: 
-Lorocco y queso (Salvadorian veggies and cheese)
-Chicken and cheese
-Super vegetariana
-Spinach and cheese
-Ground pork and cheese

All were delicious (yeah i had a bite of each).
author: Winnie L.

description:
Their pupusas are just as good as the ones in El Salvador! Balompié is our go-to spot when we are homesick. Their pupusas are not greasy! If it's your first time I recommend:

-Yuca con chicharron (good to share)
-Bean and cheese pupusa
-Bean pupusa
-"Revuelta" pupusa
-Bean and cheese pupusa made with rice flour
If you have room, get an order of fried plantains and enjoy with a cup of coffee or hot chocolate. 

The only thing wrong with this place and the Capp st. location is the lack of parking so be ready to hunt for a spot. The food will be worth your trouble, I promise!
author: Dina S.

description:
My partner and I went this afternoon to try a Mexican Restaurant nearby that was highly recommended by friends.  Although their website states they open at 4pm for early dinner, it does not open until 5pm.

We were both very hungry and knew the wait would be a killer so as we walked a short half block further out Mission Street, we found the Balompie Cafe 3.

Kismet moment:  While in the hospital Wed-Fri week before last for a lengthy spinal surgery, one of the nurses that took my B/P one evening strongly recommended this place.  She is a native born Salvadoran who loves good pupusas just like I do.

We ordered two pupusas each, a revueltas for each of us, and one queso for me and one frijoles con queso for my partner.  The fresh and fragrant curtido that was delivered to the table along with two large glasses of ice water as we requested, gave us a hint of what was about to appear. 

Sitting at a perfect table alongside the small street Balompie sits on at Mission St., and knowing that a wonderful snack that we ordered, just to catch a rest before our intended restaurant opened for dinner service, changed our plans for this evening, and has changed the way we think about pupusas in San Francisco!!

Unbelievably fresh pupusas, deliciously prepared, amazingly speedy and attentive service, flavorful and fresh curtido and the delicious homemade hot tomato sauce served alongside, and we were in heaven!  After just our first bite, we decided to try the Mexican restaurant another night and to forever include Balompie Cafe 3 in our list of top restaurants in San Francisco.

Having eaten pupusas at more Salvadoran restaurants than we care to admit to trying, enjoying them at home with friends who hail from El Salvador, as well as enjoying them half cooked and given to us by friend's relatives, that we have finished off at home, have all paled by comparison to the amazingly hot, delicious, fresh, fluffy, chock full, gorgeous and tasty pupusas served to us at Balompie Cafe 3 this afternoon.  We simply CANNOT wait to go back for more and to ultimately try all of the various choices listed on their menu for $2.50 a piece, as well as all of the specialty choices listed for but $1 more...!!!

You simply must try this place, try their delicious food, and experience their amazing service.  This is a MUST try location spot on any restaurant list.

Fondly remembering my first bite still...
author: Bruce I.

description:
3 pupusas + 1 chile relleno + 1 drunk Swedish guy = yay!

My love for pupusas started a long time ago, when my first Salvadoran friend brought me the ones freshly made by her mom. After that, I was pretty much ruined, as nothing came quite close to tasting like homemade deliciousness.

Fast forward to 2014 and I finally get to try Balompie after hearing about them from a friend. We ordered 3 different pupusas, a chile relleno plate and waited about 15-20 minutes outside for it. It was a pretty busy night, and there were other people waiting outside also. 
While waiting, the funniest and nicest drunk Swedish businessman came up and started to talk to us. (no, really, he wasn't a bum). Our food came out, just as the cops arrived to chat with him. How sad, would have loved to hear more Swedish stories over some freshly fried pupusas. 

When we got home, the food was still hot, the sauce with the chile was yummy, and the pupusas still delicious. They were probably the best ones I've had so far, and I feel like I take any opportunity I can to eat them. Will definitely come back to eat them fresh at the restaurant, five stars if the Swedish guy is there again!
author: Jade T.

description: Best pupusas! Bomb chicken. Only reason its not 5 stars is because the fried plantains are a hit or miss sometimes are way too soggy.
author: Giovanie R.

description: Best pupusas in SF! My family is Salvadoran so we literally have tried ALL of the places in the City and there are really good ones but Balompie is the absolute best!
author: Justin W.

description: This place has the feel of of a friendly laid back eating place.. love the Pupusas there .. and the Guacamole and chips are the best ...  there have been times i have just gone there to have their regular coffee... ! very friendly service.. i recently took one of my friends there for pupusas and she thought it was one of the best she had ever had .. and she is very particular about the food.. so i would say it was a win win... :)
author: Madhulika G.

description:
Umm..I was hesitant on coming here since I already have a papusa spot I goto all the time, El Zocalo! I was happy I came, I have never seen proscuitto papusa before and it was good! We over ordered..
Plantains- good!
Some meat platter combo with Steak and Chorizo- Steak was good, I didn't like the chorizo.
Pastelles- I think that's what they are called, they look like Empanadas, these were good.
I think I would go back for papusas with interesting fillings.
author: Karen T.

description: Food was good. Waiter was friendly. Would recommend.                On a scale of George Clooney to Donald Trump, I give it a Neil deGrasse Tyson.
author: Timothy Z.

description: This place has the best pupusas in town (hands down). I had two cheese and zucchini with cheese pupusas and they were really tasty and flavorful. I couldn't stop stuffing my face with them. The pupusas had about a 5 inch diameter, big enough to fill myself with only 2.   Their curtido is one of the best I've ever had. I normally don't eat curtido at all but this one complimented the food very well. It had a tarty taster....I finished my meal with a side of plantains for dessert. I know i over ordered because I couldn't finish my meal and only took a bite from the plantains.
author: Jorge J.

description:
Pupusas here are amazing. They have simpler pupusas for $2.50 each, and "special" pupusas (steak, shrimp, etc.) for $3.50 each. Two is easily enough to fill you up. I usually go for the ground pork and the steak ones with cheese. They provide plenty of curtido and tomato sauce for you to use. I got it with a fairly large glass of horchata.

They have other items on their menu too, but usually just the two pupusas is more than enough for me so I haven't tried any of them. I saw some other people order them though and the portions are very generous.

Service here is really friendly, and the staff will periodically check in on you to make sure everything is good and if you need more condiments. And if you're a big soccer fan, this place is always playing games on the TV screen.

I hear they have another store somewhere in the Mission but apparently this one is better. I'm sure you can't go wrong with either though and they'll be great environments to enjoy a Salvadorean meal.
author: Allen C.

description: Most likely you are not going to be in the area if this place if you like papusas then this is a great place to get one. The masa has a great texture with a golden crust. Order the platter with at least 1 of the pork and enjoy. The frijoles are pretty darned good as well :)
author: David B.

description: I liked this place enough that I might go back for dinner, for a cheap and cheerful dinner. I was a little disappointed by the pupusas however, I don't know if this is the traditional way but it did taste a bit like it was just two corn tortillas with cheese inside. Didn't taste much else in there, and didn't think the shrimp and cheese, or the chicken and cheese tasted any different. Service was a bit chaotic, no one got their food at the same time. Guacamole was, however, one of the best I have ever eaten (and I have eaten a lot of guacamole).
author: Anne M.

description: Been to so many pupusa spots all over the Bay Area and this place tops them all. When I'm in the mood for a pupusa making the drive to city is always worth it.
author: Mitch L.

description: I have been a huge fan of Balompies on 18th Street and thought I would check out this one on Mission Street near Richland. I was pretty disappointed in that there is a drastic difference in customer service here then there is at the original one on 18th Street! Now I have to be fair in that it may be that they are understaffed here and they feel that customer service Kevin go out the window and that is acceptable to all the folks that are crazy about the food! I do love their food and its unparalleled at either location. But I don't believe I will be coming back here until I know that they are fully staffed and that staff is happy to see customers similar to what you get when you arrive at the 18th Street location! I wonder why there is such a difference other than maybe they are overworked!
author: Jim S.

description: Yum! This is one of my favorite places to order pupusas. Eating here is awesome but you don't have to, they take phone orders and they are ready within 15 minutes! I usually order pork and cheese and they are amazing. So full of cheese and flavor! I order 3 and end up full from 2. The curtido leaves a bit to be desired as it's not too pickled but the chicharonnes are fried to perfection! I like to order the yuca and chicharonnes plate plate. There isn't much parking here but if you can find some I would definitely eat here.
author: Paula P.

description: So good.  Fresh and delicious. In addition to standard papusas, they also have specialty papusas, not to be missed
author: Dan S.

description:
W O W.

Please do yourself a favor and do try one of their famous pupusas!

I had the pleasure of trying the chicken and cheese pupusa and it was so good! It was very soft and the chicken was tender and flavorful- and to believe my meal ended up being under $10. Holla to all the ballers on a budget!

Definitely a gem in the San Francisco eateries!
author: C M.

description: Honestly, not even playing right now, best pupousa place in SF. This is in the heart of the mission. Really great pupousas. I highly recommend the tamales as well. They are very soft and very tasty. I'll definitely be coming be coming back
author: Victor A.

description: The super vegetariana pupusa was pretty tasty. I also really liked the red sauce and the cabbage that came with pupusas. The plantains were sweet, but I wish they'd be less oily. My companion had the chicharron pupusa (I tried a bite, it was okay), some fried chicken that I didn't get to try and the chicken tamale, which I didn't like that much. So, order a pupusa or two, that's your best bet here.
author: Olga A.

description:
MmM...Papusa's! 

Papusa's are delicious, and is exactly what I was craving. Balompie's delivered VERY WELL!

I had the Pork/Cheese and the Chicken Cheese. Both were DELICIOUS and was perfect. What you do with this, in case you're a noob, is to cut the papusa into smaller bites, then load each bite with their coleslaw-like cabbage mixture, and their spicy sauce.  Together in one bite is all types of yum. 

Also had the fried plantains, and they were very good too! The plantains were done perfectly, and a few even had an extra crisp to the side.

Our waitress was attentive and very helpful. We were there during a football (football, not soccer. FOOTBALL) match, and though I'm not a huge football fan, the excitement of others was quite contagious.  That, and the nice elderly people who smiled patronizingly at me while I ate and others cheered. ha.
author: Lily W.

description: Great food, great service, best pupasa's I've ever had in my life. I found this place on yelp and had to try it out for myself.  How did I never know about this  place?! Pretty busy on a weekday lunch hour so I can only imagine how long the wait is on the weekend. I didn't have to wait at all.  Everyone even the other customers were friendly. I appreciate great customer service on top of great food. Will for sure be back!!!
author: Quan B.

description:
3.5 stars, it's good but not quite there.

Place is nice and open.  Came here on a Friday night and parking wasn't hard to find.   Service was eh, it was there, but not warm.  

Of course we got the pupusas and a side of platanos with crema since know just the pupusas alone with fill us up.  Hubby wanted to order more since he thought it wasn't enough but boy was he wrong.  He said 2 pupusas for him was just right.  Hubby loves latin american food, but not really of pupusas.  After trying it here, he now understands why I like it.  In comparison to other places, he can taste the freshness and flavor.  
We loved the pork pupusas, very flavorful.  As for the chicken, we felt like we couldn't taste any chicken.  
I prefer the El Salvadorian horchata than Mexican, but the horchata here was bland.  Just didn't have any enough flavor.  

Overall, place was good, but when we left the restaurant, I started wondering about how good the other pupusas spot nearby.  I'll do a comparison first then after that, maybe I'll come back to this place.
author: Claire J.

description:
Very tasty pupusas at very reasonable prices (2 for about $5) in a part of the mission that isn't too crowded or crazy. I have tried the ground pork and cheese pupusa, the salvadoran vegetables and cheese pupusa, and the chicken and cheese pupusa. All were quite tasty, but my favorite was the ground pork.

The decor is very soccer related and they usually have a futbol game on. I'd say there is about 12-15 tables there of various sizes and a bar. Pretty standard, not too dirty or clean.

The only thing stopping me from giving it 5 stars is the service is a little on the slow side, even w/ the check. Also, w/ this being numbe 3, is it a chain?
author: Vincent-Arthur B.

description:
The best pupusas. Hot, freshly made, with a crisp exterior and melty cheese and fillings that are chunky enough to tell what they are (that's important). Good sides and good cabbagey stuff, and the staff are always friendly. There's a soccer game on at least one of the TVs, so you can watch that too.
Also very important: super inexpensive. So affordable. Just outstanding. It's 3 blocks from my house so I'd go there all the time even if it wasn't good, but there is literally no where else I'd go for pupusas.
author: Amanda M.

description:
I've previously been to the Balompie Cafe in the Mission and I love both locations! The ambiance is quite different at each cafe; this one is a little better well-lit, cleaner, and just a 15-minute walk from my place in Bernal Heights... plain dangerous because their food is so good.

I've been here once with one friend and we shared 3 pupusas and the plantain empanada with custard filling. Loved everything! Of the pupusas we got that night, I liked the Mexicana y Queso one the best; the ground pork (chorizo?), jalapenos and cheese were just oozing out of the fresh tortilla.

The plantain empanada was unexpected in the most wonderful way. Most plantain dishes I've had are served in chunks and with beans. Though Balompie does have a bean option for the plantain empanada (and that is also reaaaally delicious), the custard filling really wins here! It's the perfect way to end the meal... something sweet, with a soft, creamy filling, a burst of fresh plantain flavor, and the deep-fried crunch on the outside!

I can't wait to come back again and try some new dishes. Made me smile when Katie W.'s review pointed out how Balompie #2 is in El Salvador! No wonder I couldn't find it after much effort on Yelp!
author: Tracy W.

description:
Say it three times w/ me: Balompie Balompie Balompie. Fun name, but where in the world did it come from? No clue.

Why Balompie even?  Well, the 7x7 list of course. Pupusas it says, try it. So I took the kiddos for a quick ride to Bernal Heights, and we tried 'em. 

We ordered four kinds: chicken, shrimp, carne asada, and pork...all w/cheese. The two ladies cooked them right in front of us @the bar. Very authentic! She smiled, played patty cake w/the dough and filling, formed them into a ball, flattened them out, then placed them on the grill... all the while humming quietly & smiling. Sweet ladies!!  

Ten minutes later, the pupusas came steaming hot & served w/pickled cabbage & salsa. They were all very good, but used a tad bit too much grease. Too oily for my taste. Even the tamales were hounded in grease. Not quite what I was expecting.

Bottom line: What happened to our Pupusa Party?? Well, maybe it was just the luck of the draw that it turned out too oily. Try again another time? Maybe!

Tip: As others have mentioned, you get charged more per dish if you dine in.
author: Joy A.

description: Best place for pupusas hands down! I haven't found a better place so far. Wait is a little long sometimes but well worth it.
author: Sneha M.

description:
Pupusanator, where are you? Balompie has divine pupusas.  I love that they offer over a dozen kinds of pupusas including some non-traditional kinds and they shape them by hand in front of you.  The pile of masa is huge.

The pupusas come with a generous heap of crunchy, tangy, slightly spicy shredded cabbage & carrot slaw and a cup of tomato sauce (didn't need the sauce because the fillings were so flavorful).  I ordered a few to go and stuck them in the toaster till the cheese inside melted and the outside was slightly crispy.  You can see finger indentations in these lovely discs of masa.  They're not dense or bland like some pupusas.

* Italiana Y Queso (prosciutto & cheese filling) pupusa - amazing combo of salty prosciutto, creamy mild cheese and bits of fresh basil surrounded by tender masa 
* Pescado Y Queso pupusa - Filled with delicious bits of fish (not fried) and melted mild cheese, tons of flavor

The menu is very interesting and includes breakfast items, combo plates, enchiladas, empanadas, tamales, pastels, etc. The Salvadorean turkey sandwich features salsa.

* Salpicon is a chopped beef salad with tiny bits of radish, onion and fresh mint ($8.95). The appearance surprised me.  It looked like tuna salad.  The shredded beef was chopped so finely and was also super dry. It's simmered for hours and the recipes I looked at said the beef is supposed to be tender.  I liked the salad flavors and the textures (except the beef).  Tapatio and a squeeze of lemon helped with the dryness.  The sides were good - creamy beans, fluffy rice pilaf, a simple fresh green salad with a tangy dressing and two thick handmade corn tortillas (much thicker than usual, more like plain unfilled pupusas than tortillas).

There's a wood counter where you can sit and eat while you watch them cook (they know what they're doing with all the flipping and pupusa making) or catch a soccer game. Soccer scarves adorn the walls.
author: Lolia S.

description: Anytime I'm missing my moms cooking I stop by and feel a little better. This is by far the most authentic Salvadorian food in the city!!! I normally get the platanos, frijoles, y crema and it's as delicious as if my great grandmother made it! The plantains are always sweet and soft unlike other places I've been to. The refried beans are authentic and don't taste like they came out of a can. Everyone who works there is super friendly and welcoming! I'm glad there is a place I can go to when I'm craving some bomb food!
author: Sherry G.

description: I came here for lunch, ordered yuca frita with chicharrones. The food was delicious, service was great. My friend ordered the pupusas and they were the Best. I recommend it.
author: Milly H.

description: Good food bad customer service    The Waitress didn't  even acknowledge us  when we came in . One of the workers where sitting and eating  in the dining area . She put her plate away and went to work . Our waitress was more in  involved with one of the coworker that was giving her massage. So unprofessional never did she ask if we needed anything . I hope the owner reads  this and give his employees a course on being professional .
author: Elizabeth M.

description: This location is very convenient but the food is not as good as their location on Capp. I often order pupusas  for pick up for parties or for quick dinners but often times the masa is raw. They take a long time to fill the order yet my items are not properly cooked.
author: Sandra R.

description:
One pupusa, 
Two pupusas, 
Three pupusas, 
FOUR!

Actually, my friend and I got six. Just to be extra sure we wouldn't go hungry. 

I've been slackin on my Big Eat SF list and since my partner in crime Patty P. has already been here, I was happy to snag another friend who was wiling to go with me, so I can check off another item:

#32 Pupusas at Balompie Cafe #3

We decided to get two of each and try three fillings:  Spinach and cheese, beans and cheese, pork and cheese.   These doughy pancake-like thick tortillas are definitely cheesy and a bit greasy as well. The pork was too salty for my taste and the beans didn't really do it for me.  I was surprised that I liked the spinach and cheese pupusas the best.  You get a small bowl of pickled vegetables, which counteracts some of the saltiness of the pork.   Chips and salsa are complimentary while you wait for your pupusas. 

Be aware that you get charged a little extra for dining in.  (Pupusas are $2.50 each compared to the take out price of $1.95)   There were quite a few tables available for seating and the bathroom is clean.  It was cold inside so definitely bring your coat with you.  

We stayed here for two hours and our server was nice enough to constantly check up on us but didn't kick us out.  I got some much needed gossip time and the trip to Bernal Heights is worth it.
author: Janice C.

description: Yum yum! I have been going to the original Balompie for years, but have never made it out to #3 until today.  It's a bit smaller but brighter and cleaner than the original and the pupusas were just as good!  Only tried the Loroco and Mexicana - which are my go-tos and they were awesome.  If you are further out in Mission/Bernal then hit up this one!
author: Gene X.

description:
This place is pupusa heaven. You can see them making them fresh right behind the counter, and oh my, they are delicious. Pork and cheese, spinach and cheese, chicken, whatever one you order, you will be amazed.

I ordered the sampler plate, and it was good, don't get me wrong. But, I think I should've just ordered more pupusas. Soooo good!

One more thing - cool soccer decorations with scarves and flags. A nice, calm, bright place to have some food and watch some World Cup commentary.
author: Ryan C.

description: Some of the best pupusas around and that's saying a lot because the competition is fierce in this area.
author: colleen w.

description:
This (and Balompie #1 on 18th St in the Mission) is my favorite place in the city for pupusas.  Everybody's kind of said why the food is great, but I wanted to throw in a few fun facts:

First, this Balomie is Balompie #3, and the one on 18th doesn't have a number (presumably it is #1), but I always wondered where #2 was, turns out (from their website) it's in El Salvador!  Doesn't get much more authentic than that, where the #2 is out of the country.

Second, at this location (as opposed to the one on 18th) you can watch the cooks make the pupusas right there, slide them on a plate and put them in front of you about 3 feet away.  They are masterful, and fun to watch (and study for technique!).
author: Katie W.

description: Great hole in the wall with a nice design. Food freshly made and tasty. First time trying pupusas and delicious! Two minimum @ $2.50 is worth it. Will try it again soon. Chicken tamales also where fresh and delicious!!
author: LL Y.

description: First place I've ever tried pupusas mixed with jalepeno or spinach and carrots.. freakin amazing!!! I'm a hard core el zócalo fan but I think it's time for a change
author: Mimi W.

description:
So, my friend and I decided to eat our way through the Mission one day. We started off here, ordering the recommended Salvadorean Sampler.

The sampler comes with a pupusa of your choice, a pastel of your choice and yuca with your choice of protein. 
For the pupusa we picked the loroco (a Salvadorean vegetable that my friend said reminded her of spinach) and cheese filling. The pastel (like an empanada) we chose had chicken  and our yuca was steamed and came with grilled shrimp. 
The pupusa was very flavorful, but a little oily for my taste. Super soft dough, though.
The pastel is delish! Nice filling and the crust is perfect.
Yuca= yum! I totally recommend getting the steamed rather than the fried, its a nice break from all the other greasy foods. 

The service was slow. Besides us, there were two other parties and it took a while to get our food. This was made up for by the yummy salsa and slaw-like cabbage and the delicious food. 

CASH ONLY!
author: dina s.

description:
So good
The papusas are worth traveling an hour.
The smelt with fried yuca WOW...
cafe con Leche-Yummy
all good must try.
author: M.P R.

description: We decided to come here for dinner after visiting the de young museam and we were starving. We saw that the pupusas at this place is on the 7x7 top 100 things to eat in SF for this year so we had to get some. The famous one according to the list is the chicarron (pork) pupusa. It was one of my favorite from the night. They are fresh made to order and it tastes so good with the cheese and meat. My girl and I both ordered 3 different ones each and shared. We got the Italiano which comes with prosciutto which you can probably skip. It was tasty but not amazing. We got the shrimp which was my favorite of the night. The seafood was fresh and went well with the sauce and slaw that comes with your pupusas. We also got the fish and cheese which was equally as good as the shrimp but I've always had a soft spot for shrimp. My fav. All the seafood pupusas were my favorite from this night as well as the chicarron. Perfect flavor combos with the cheese and sauce. So bomb. We also got chicken which was also good and ground beef which you can also skip. Overall a good spot to get your grub on and it's not too expensive. We got lucky with street parking but usually it's a pain. Come here and grab the fish, shrimp or chicarron pupusas. You won't be sorry.
author: Jeromy G.

description:
Pretty good overall - for two we ordered 4 pupusas (pork and cheese, pork cheese and jalapeno, steak and cheese, and zucchini and cheese), chicken soup, and a combo plate with chile relleno and a pork and mint dish. This was way too much food for 2 people so I don't recommend ordering that much. The pupusas were really good - the pork and cheese especially. The rest of the food tasted pretty standard - definitely not bad but not amazing or anything. 

Good place to stop by if you're in the area, and good service too.
author: Leily P.

description: Pupusas are so freakn good! Usually, I like pupusas revueltas (with cheese and meat) but here I get my pupusa with cheese only because they stuff it so much! Soo good..but so bad (more gym time and sit ups required)...still, hands down my fav spot for pupusas...gracias Balompie
author: Laura M.

description: Pupusas are amazing here, the service was also great! I liked the culturals memorabilia on the walls too.
author: Chris T.

description:
3.5.

Great location, but parking can be a challenge.  Solid food, but a big complaint is that their chicharrones papusas had hardly any meat! I would like to see them add some type of vegetables to their menu.  Food is very flavorful, but heavy.  Come with an empty belly!
author: Danielle E.

description:
I've been on a pupusa kick lately and I guessed by the reviews this is the place this is.
They have much more than the cheese, cheese and chicharron, cheese and bean and cheese and loroco.
They have an open kitchen, you can see the pupusas being made to order.
author: Geordie E.

description:
A friend recommended this place and then wasn't able to join us due to illness. We ordered extra so he could enjoy the food too. This place is great for good food at an inexpensive price. The pupusas are either $2.50 or $3.50 for the specialty ones like "Mejicana y Queso" which is ground pork, jalapenos and cheese. Regular ones like zucchini and cheese, beans and cheese, or spinach and cheese are $2.50. All said, there are 14 different kinds of pupusas, so there should be something for everyone's taste. We added to our order a breakfast combo of fried plantains, refried beans, sour cream and cheese. The pupusas come with a hot sauce and coleslaw type of condiment. 

There are several draft beers and bottled beer to round out your meal if you want alcohol. 

The decor is simple and service friendly enough. Parking is tough to find, so allow extra time to drive around looking for a space.
author: Scott S.

description: Small place but the food is yummy! Husband and I decided to try this place while in the area, we were greeted and seated as soon as we walked in, service was great, our waitress was friendly and attentive. Their agua de tamarindo is delicious, didn't taste watered down like a lot of places I've encountered. I had the veggie, bean & cheese, and spinach & cheese pupusas and oh man they were delicious! They were a little stingy with the curtido tho. The husband had the mexicano, italiano, and revuelta.. I think the italiano was the only one he didn't finish but we kinda expected it to be a little weird anyway and he wouldn't shut up about how properly fried the empanadas were. The bill was super cheap too, Will definitely return!
author: Betty G.

description:
My favorite pupusas. Always in the mood to go there and have a great meal. 
very affordable and its a comfortable spot to be. good for any occasion.
author: andrew p.

description: Curtido please. Can't get enough of that. Two pupusas will fill a 5'8" 165lb guy. I almost manage to finish the third. It was just like the pupusas I had in El Salvador 10 years ago, but a bit less greasy, which is great. The girl making the pupusas is hella cute. I hope she's still there.
author: Troy V.

description: Great for vegetarians, super affordable, good service, comfortable seating, and above all delicious! I will be dreaming about those pupusas.
author: Krista A.

description: Omg love this place the pupusas are bomb! Better then La Santaneca (across the street, not the 24th and mission one)  and let me tell u I grew up eating at La Santaneca and they were good but Balompie won me over with their pupusas! Not greasy yet chessey gooy inside love it!
author: Evelyn Sophia C.

description:
Mmmm, pupusas!!! I love it so far. I am giving them 5 stars and really hope it stays there, but I do have to do some more exploring here. Came here one weekend morning as part of our pupusa/tamal crawl through our new neighborhood. It is a really neat, cozy little cafe with flat screen TVs, a coffee bar, soccer playing non-stop, and beer on tap! Never seen a Salvadorean restaurant quite like it. 

Anyway, I ordered the pupusas revueltas with beans, pork, and cheese (about $2.50 each) and one that I think was called an Italiano that had prosciutto in it (about $3.50). I also ordered two tamales, one chicken and one pork. Finally, I got the pollo guisado, one of my faves. All of this was to go and I ordered a coffee while I waited. The pupusas were awesome, probably the best that I have had in my neighborhood so far. I actually liked the revueltas better than the Italiano, but all were good. The tamal de puerco was fantastic as well, but I was really sad that I did not receive the tamal de pollo that I ordered. All is forgiven though because they also did not charge me for it. I appreciate the very kind lady trying to watch my weight for me and I would have picked the pork over chicken anyway. 

The pollo guisado was just alright and would have knocked them down to 4 stars. It was breast meat and was very, very dry. I didn't even think to specifically request dark meat, but I'm sure it would have been much better with dark meat. Nevertheless, this still was not the best guisado that I have had, so maybe I will just stick to something else in the future. The reason that I did not drop them down a star is because the have beer on tap. Not just that, but they have Sierra, Blue Moon, and I think it was Newcastle on tap for like $3.50-4.00ish. They also have some Salvadorean and Mexican bottle beers for the same prices. Also, the atmosphere is just so cool. Not your usual hole-in-the-wall type of place. Don't get me wrong, I love those places, but this place was very refreshing. Would love to come here for brunch with friends sometime soon, maybe catch some Futbol!
author: Miguel V.

description:
I travel around a lot for work, all locally. For my sanity, it's always good to find cheap, clean, good eat spots to take breaks in between work appointments.
Driving from one side of SF to another, I drove past Balompie, and immediately started saluvating when I read "Salvadorean," (a.k.a. pupusas). I'm a sucker for pupusas.
The place was empty, and they were able to accomodate my order for takeout.
About 15 minutes and $5 later, I walked out with my lunch: two pupusas with loroco and cheese, topped with pickled cabbage and carrots, and hot sauce.
I'll be back, the soccer games playing throughout the place make it an awesome spot to watch Ronaldo kick butt.
author: Alyssa G.

description: The pupusas here are the best I have had, whole family agrees. I had the shrimp & cheese and chicken & cheese, so fresh! Delicious!
author: Tina A.

description:
Decent food (grilled steak-in-tomato sauce, plantains, horchata), decent service. 

Soccer flair + big screen TV.
author: Inigo M.

description:
While my wife and I was in the city the other day with some time to kill, we decided to try out Balompie Café and their famous assortment of Pupusas. I use to eat a lot of Pupusas in my younger days, but just recently I started eating this delicious traditional Salvadoran dish once more. Balompie Café most definitely ignited my pupusas craving in a monstrous kind of way. Not in a gruesome fashion, but more like cookie monster's obsessive craving for cookies. 

Balompie Café's Pupusas are without a doubt one of the best pupusas I have ever eaten. I would even say it's one of the best food I've ever tasted. For me it's a tossup between the oh so delicious Shrimp Pupusas & Cheese and the comparably succulent Fish Pupusas & Cheese. I've also had the Chicken Pupusas & Cheese, but that's a distant third in my book (although my wife really loves the chicken). Like what you have read in many of the other reviews, they make the pupusas fresh and as you order them, so there will be some wait time after your order. 

This corner café is not very roomy, so it could get very crowded, but I personally love little cafés because it adds that coziness and informal feel to the place, see Brenda's French Soul Food. The atmosphere really shows the owners passion for soccer, obviously evident by the endless soccer reruns shown on the flat screen TV above the refrigerator. 

I really don't have any reason why I wouldn't give this place a 5 star rating. So Balompie Café, "Woohoo! As good as it gets!"
author: Mel B.

description:
Personally, I think this place has the best pupusas in S.F. 

Zocalo, Los Panchos...both great!  But I really love coming here.  Their pupusas are greasy and the cheese just spills out, making them yummy and crunchy.  Their Steak Encebollado is also really really good!

FYI: The Balompie in the Mission is not as good as the one in Bernal Heights.
author: Anthony Xavier S.

description: Today I had 2 Pupusas: de Chicharon (pork) y una de Loroco con Queso (Salvadorian vegetable) with a side order for Plantains.  This place ROCKS! LOVE, LOVE, LOVE the food!
author: Marisol P.

description: Fantastic Pupusas! This is a no-frills, inexpensive, and friendly place. I ordered and waited for take-out, it did not take long, and the food was excellent.
author: karen d.

description:
The best of both worlds: Blue Moon on tap and Pupusas!  Aimed right at this Salvadorean American girl's heart.  
Don't miss out on the picked veggies with jalapenos my new craving and I'm not even pregnant anymore.  
Can not wait to go back!
author: La C.

description: Best pupusas!  Just ate here for the first time last night and I was very impressed. I don't think I can ever eat pupusas from El Zocalo again. Had the sopa de res as well and that was delicious.  One of my new fave spots!
author: Stacey C.

description:
Of the four or so Salvadorean restaurants I've frequented within my neighborhood, Balompie stands far above the rest. Their prompt service and absolutely delicious food is accompanied by a clean environment and friendly atmosphere. 

I must take away one star for the entrees always taking an extended amount of time to prepare. But, this is to be expected when the food is freshly prepared.

The dish to try is the Salvadorean Sampler, especially with the carne asada. The steak is consistently fresh and properly trimmed. The yucca's texture is perfect and the pupusas are delectable without being overly greasy.

If you're ever in the Glen Park or Bernal Heights area, be sure to check out this first-rate eatery.
author: Elliot R.

description: Over priced pupusas although they do have many different combinations you can choose from. Restaurant is small but looks nice. Employees are friendly. Been awhile since I've been there so I'll give it another try and get back to you. Stay tuned!
author: Cesar B.

description:
I LOVE THESE PUPUSAS! I've been here a handful of times & I have enjoyed every single visit! 

The food is delicious & their menu has interesting and new Pupusas that I've never seen on any other menu. I hate when pupusas are greasy, and these ones are not which makes me love this place even more!

The restaurant is small & parking is slightly difficult BUT the 49 stops RIGHT IN FRONT & you can call ahead and order food to go (which is at a slight discount) and it's usually ready for you when you get there. That means, grab a driver, and let them circle the block if you don't want to look for parking & by the time they get back, you'll be outside waiting.

This place is worth it. Seriously, try them out if you're looking for a good pupuseria.
author: Rebecca L.

description: 2 outta 3 times pupusas had a hair in them but then again who doesn't like hair in there pupusas!!! Planes de Renderos is better
author: A A.

description:
It was San Fran Adventure day. My friend and I took BART to Balboa Park station and just started walking northeast with no particular destination or itinerary in mind.
The first couple hours were in the Excelsior area, full of lots of colorful homes and pretty views from the hilltops. 
By the time we reached the Mission, we were very hungry, and literally stopped at the first restaurant we came upon. Thankfully it was Balompie. We saw the word "Pupuseria" on the window and it was a done deal.
The cafe is nice: totally casual, but not grimy or anything. It had a cool hammered copper bar behind which a woman was vigorously slapping dough to form pupusas. 
It took a little longer than expected for the entrees to come, but we munched on the zesty curtido slaw salad while we waited.
We each had a Mexicana y Queso pupusa, which was perfectly prepared, with a toasty doughy outside and a gooey cheese inside with some chorizo inside. 
We split an order of the salpicon which was a new dish to me. It sounded like and indeed was reminiscent of Laotian laap or Thai larb. Rather than chicken or pork, it was shredded beef with mint and radishes. Very tasty.
I had a tall glass of horchata, which was cinnamony perfection. 
Two elderly Salvadorean men sat next to us, both singing the praises of this eatery's adherence to the tastes of their homeland. Definitely work checking out.
author: Adam C.

description:
OMG, love the platanos!  One of these days I will visit and try something else other than pupusas, but the cheesy goodness is too yummy!

Love the staff here, so friendly and attentive!
author: Mabelle A.

description:
I seriously crave Balompie everytime I'm in the city.

Famous for their pupusas which are all made to order, meaning you can hear the people smacking the masa around in their hands while you're seated.  I guess that makes the food a bit of a wait but who cares when you know the food is fresh?

I've only had the pupusas and tamales from here and nothing else from their menu, but they do have a selection of other food for those who aren't in the mood.

I appreciate that they have so many varieties of pupusas, not just the standard cheese, pork, and beans. Still, I always seem to gravitate to the chicharron and queso, and even just the plain queso.

Enjoy the pupusas with a hearty scoop of their curtido and hot sauce, and you're in Salvadorean heaven.
author: Gina L.

description:
I had one of the yummiest gluten free dinners here!

Had a spinach & and a zucchini pupusa + rice & beans. Pupusas are a Salvadorian dish made with corn flour. Comfort food yum...

And the atmosphere is so nice. Like a neighborhood cafe. Talked with folks about the World Cup games while waitin on my food to arrive. Got to watch ladies behind the bar make the pupusas. 

Easygoing week day din din.
author: Sara L.

description: The food was really good! This was my first time having food from El Salvador, and it exceeded my expectations. The pupusas are amazing. Also, the plantains are to die for. The pan con pavo sandwich wasn't that great though, didn't really have any flavor. I'd recommend to just get pupusas and fried plantains for anyone who hasn't been here before, as they are delicious.
author: Alexander M.

description:
It was amazing!! went there mid-week and it was fantastic !! being part Salvadoran.. i love me some pupusas!! 

*+1= for the great  LOW prices!! 
*+1= the menu options 
*+1= location and take- out option!!
*+1= service!! 

over all great place.. we got pupusas $2.10 each .. best one is cheese and loroco. & pork and cheese!!
author: Char K.

description:
I learned about Balompie from many of those food lists. So when I thought of a super popular place for pupusas, I imagined a super homely hole in the wall. But instead, Balompie Cafe 3 is this super nice modern cafe with a nice TV and football (soccer) decor everywhere. 

The menu was impressive for me too, there were many veggie pupusas to choose from. I was so excited when they finally came. It was the best pupusas I have ever eaten. But this is of course coming from a little Asian girl. I don't really know the correct standards for judging pupusas but they sure do taste good to me! I had the special vegetarian pupusa and one with Salvadorian veggies and cheese.

The pupusa had just the right ratio of flour and filling for me. The salsa was also delicious. While it was really good, two pupusas were really hard for me to finish. For anyone with a normal to smaller appetite, two pupusas will be enough. 

The pricing for the pupusas is different for dining in and taking out. Cheaper to take out.
author: Angela T.

description:
Be sure and order item #14 on the menu at this scrumptious restaurant. This includes 2 Papusa's, rice and beans. I ordered a chicken/cheese and a pork Papusa which were both excellent. My wife, who is a vegetarian ordered cucumber. 

In addition to our Papusa plates, my wife and i each ordered a Fat Tire beer and and some fried plantains thus resulting in a perfect dinner.
author: Steve M.

description:
Yum! The papusas were fresh and hot...you can see the ladies making them behind the counter. I tried the pork and cheese, and fish and cheese. I preferred the pork and cheese, but my friend liked the fish and cheese. This means both were delicious!

The papusas were served with a salsa/hot sauce, and pickled cabbages. Man, the pickled cabbages are good!! I ate each bite of papusa with some salsa and cabbage on top. Very good. 

Why not 5 stars? Kinda pricey! The pork and cheese was $2.50, and the fish and cheese was $3.50. I'd come here often it papusas were cheaper...
author: Carol L.

description:
7x7 list - pupusas from balompie cafe no. 3

ordered, to go, b/c it's cheaper than eating in:
frijoles y queso pupusa
camaron y queso pupusa (cashier misheard my order for chicharon y queso)
mejicana y queso pupusa
carne asada y queso pupusa
carne tamale

total price: 13.74

included: lots of pickled vegetables and salsa that wasn't spicy  enough though we requested it be spicy. that's okay.

the woman making the pupusas is very good, doesn't use excess dough, though she uses excess cheese, which is always okay in my book! 

i'm used to the pupusas at the Saturday Alemany Farmers' Market from Estrellita's Snacks so I do have a comparison to make. Estrellita's are oilier, doughier, have less filling inside, but are more flavorful. Balompie's are, well, the opposite. They do have more choices than Estrellita and are much cheaper! 

Word to the wise: if you take the pupusas home, reheat them over medium high heat until warmed through and crispy on the outside. Pam/wipe pan with oiled paper towel if necessary. Also, make sure you douse in salsa and pile on the pickled cabbage . otherwise, you're basically eating a Salvadorean quesadilla...

Now, the tamale was GREAT. i usually don't eat tamales b/c i find them plain and useless. However, this one, since it was wrapped in a banana leaf (i'm assuming...) and doused in oil -.-, the masa was fluffy and flavorful and there was a chunk of good pork inside, with a little bit of potato as well. would return for the tamales! they're only 2.75... 

do i think it should be on the 7x7 list? ehhhhhhhhhhhhh.... i suggest they trump it with estrellita's snacks. though, the value is wonderful. 

btw, they show latino espn here. :) thought that was cool.
author: Melissa C.

description: Awesome papusas! Great vegetarian options, good prices, good beer, good location - no complaints!
author: Katie B.

description: Sitting in Balompie's now, waiting for two delicious pupusas to arrive. How do I know they're delicious? I've been here five times, with a 100% success rate so far. Come here, get some pupusas. Do it now!
author: John M.

description: My new spot for delicious comida salvadorena!! I love the pupusas, platano frito, yucca..I'm going to go through that menu this year!! I love the brightness in the restaurant, very cheery. Don't like they are not open on Tuesdays. The people that work there are so nice and helpful when we want to try something new. They also have a good selection of beer. Do yourself a favor and go in even if just for a pupusa. You won't be disappointed!
author: Ale G.

description: The pupusas are soooo good :) I love the menu and the condiments they give. I went here recently after a long day of playing sports at a summer camp and it was the perfect way to relax and refuel. The staff was really nice and easy to work with. I'd definitely come here again. The only thing is that sometimes people leave the doors open so there were some flies around.
author: Kristin S.

description: Stunningly great food! Simple and yummy. Will include in our list of favorites and visit when in SF. Every dish we've tried is delicious.
author: Seth L.

description:
Hands down, best pupusas in the City.  These things are made to order, so you better not come here in a hurry expecting fast food.  The ladies are hand smacking these things with love for each order that comes in until the last customer leaves(you still see the finger imprints on the hand made finished pupusa).

Must try:  Combination plate #14 (2 pupusas + rice & beans)

Choose any of the delicious pupusas from the long list and couple it with the Salvadorean style rice & beans called casamiento.  It is a pan fried combination of the two of them and really sticks to the tummy if you know what I mean.  Delicious cabbage mixture stuff and salsa make this meal complete and you get it all for like $9.25 including tax.  

Bonus: Items are discounted when ordered for Pick-Up
author: Smiley D.

description:
This place was a hidden gem.  Being a pupusa virgin I'm happy I had my first one here :)  Place was a clean (tables, menu, and floor) neigbhoorhood joint.

The Food: I had the espinaca y queso pupusa ($2.50) and split a Regia (32oz $7.00) beer.  It hit the spot.  The pupusa (not greasy at all) reminded me of a cross between a stuffed indian paratha and quesadilla.  Remember to try their salsa and cabbage topping with your pupusa.
author: Sheetal S.

description:
Ever since I discovered the deliciousness that is a pupusa a year and a 1/2 ago, I have been trying to find the best ones in the city. 

I'm a regular at La Santaneca, but when I noticed Balompie on the corner of the next block and calling itself a "Pupuseria," I had to go in and try. 

I liked the clean setting, and took a seat at the counter. I was impressed by the variety of pupusas they offered, and that I was able to watch the Mexican cook (*NOT El Salvadorian), make them fresh to-order. 

Mine was good, but it costs $1.00 more than the others down the street, so I might as well stick to La Santaneca b/c I get more pupusa action for the buck.
author: Misha F.

description:
BEST. PUPUSAS. IN. THE. CITY.

If you like cheesy, flavorful pupusas, come here. You will NOT be disappointed. 

Plus everything else is pretty delicious too, and cheap to boot. I had the juevos rancheros and they were cheap and taste bud pleasing. 

The PLATANOS! Holy moly, I don't know how to express my love for the platanos but to just give you a picture of me groaning in ecstasy as the fried banana melts in my mouth. 

So if you happen to come by this restaurant  you MUST try the platanos and pupusas.
author: Veronica D.

description:
Pupusas were good, I really liked the fish and cheese option. They were made to order and you can see them make it!

Definitely Fresh, and you as a customer can tell this right away when you take you first bite
author: Eric A.

description:
so i finally made it to the new balompie and im happy to report the same yum yum taste in the pupusas flows with 18st balompie...i did like that this new loctaion is bigger, lil trendy and a whole lot easier to find street parking..

2 pupusas~ chicharron con queso
1 order of platanos fritos
1 horchata...ok i lie 2 horchatas....

mmm mmmm good like campbells soup....i lie again..a lot better then campbells soup jajaja
author: Ivan C.

description:
Parking is shit. Good we got that out of the way.
Food was great!!!
The chicken empanadas are very flavorful.
Pupusas are perfect! My favorite are the corn pupusas with cheese and loroco. Greasy cheesy goodness.
I also ordered the Carne Asada with Casamiento. The Carne Asada came with slightly grilled tomato, bell pepper, onions and green onions on top of it. 
The price is right 7 people ate and drank (beer) until we couldn't fit anymore for about $150- where else can you do that?
PS Limited Seating - we didn't have to wait but I am sure that when it gets busy there is a line.
author: Edi B.

description:
I hate to start a yelp entry by writing about throwing up, but ever since that burrito from Chipotle 2 years ago, I would seldom visit a Latin American restaurant. The pupusas at Balompie is the first time I truly enjoy Latino food after that incident!

(+) just the right amount of cheese, meat and greasiness
(+) extremely friendly waiters. I told the dude it was my first pupusas and was asking him numerous questions, he patiently answered everything.
author: Wayne T.

description:
I'm not really qualified to give a know-it-all review on pupusas since I've only had them once before but here's what I *can* tell you:

* Parking near this place is damn near impossible. 

* The interior was surprisingly bar-like and based on the decor, I'd bet it's JUMPING during soccer games. Noonish on a Saturday though? I was the only one there and the staff seemed surprised to have a customer.

* I ordered four pupusas, which was too many because they were bigger than expected. 

* They hand make them right there in front of you and she didn't grease the grill before cooking them so I was surprised at how greasy my pupusas were, but that was probably from the gobs of delicious, melty cheese inside.

* Tasty salsa, but I wasn't so hot for the oregano-heavy slaw.

* Also delicious but greasy: The fried plaintains.

So would I eat here again?

Maybe, but the Mission location might be a more likely destination because this one was hell and far out there.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Super delicious (and reasonably priced) pupusas.  Other food was good, but not outstanding for my taste.  Friendly but not especially attentive service.  Ample seating.  Parking a bit rough, but hey, that's SF I guess.  Entire meal for just over $10, and even with that, I took some home :o.  Can't beat that for happy value! :-)
author: Adam L.

description: Love Balompies ~ this is our favorite place to indulge in pupusas and both the vegetarians and carnivores are happy. All the pupusas sampled have been at least very good, but the pork, cheese and jalapeno with curtido slaw salad is a favorite choice. The prices are very reasonable and you can see (and hear) them making the pupusas. There is counter seating if you really want a great view of the food being created. Lunch or dinner, Balompies tends to have a full house but we haven't had to wait more than a few minutes for a table to open up. Probably not the best choice if you are in a rush, but they do offer to go service. They have a decent selection of draft beer, too. We have eaten here at least five or six times and have never been disappointed.
author: Kate G.

description:
I really wish I didn't have to do this but it's warranted. Their pupusas are still my favorite, let's make that clear. My gripe is, usually you're served chips, salsa and that pickled coleslaw stuff as soon as you're seated. Well, I got salsa and pickled coleslaw but no chips. I gave the server a few minutes to redeem herself thinking she was either busy or just forgot. Apparently I wasn't the only one - the table next to me had to ask for chips. I figured, great, maybe she'll bring me some. 

Never happened. 

A few minutes later, I saw her throw the bag of chips away in the trash. I assumed it was down to crumbs and she was going to open up a new bag. 

Never happened.

By this time, my pupusas were ready and the server brought them over so naturally I asked for chips. She told me they were all out. I was a bit disappointed but it wasn't a big deal. But before I could even cut into my pupusa I heard her say, "Excuse me..." I looked up and to my utter amazement, she had pulled the bag of chips out of the trash can with this look on her face as if to say, "unless you want these?" 

To her defense, I don't think she was trying to be rude or offending in any way, although I was a bit insulted. But truthfully, it was quite a bonehead thing to do. I politely told her "no thanks" and went back to my food, gracious that I at least had a good, sanitary pupusa in front of me.
author: O'Shea J.

description: I tried two pupusas, the super vegeteriana and the shrimp and queso and fried plantana on the side. It was ok but nothing special, certainly overrated!
author: Elias V.

description:
5 stars for the Chicharron y Queso Pupusa ($2.50) and Prosciutto Y Queso Pupusa ($3.50) + slaw [can't eat it without it], chips, and salsa

1 star for the hair in my pupusa..... =( 

4 stars for the friendly service =)

Overall..I could see myself coming back to try everything else on the menu
author: Kelley N.

description: The boyfriend and I came here to discover the greatness that is #32 on the 7x7 Big Eat SF list: Pupusas at Pupusas at Balompie Café #3.  We were welcomed by a friendly staff who brought chips and salsa to our table immediately.  We tried 3 different Pupusas-- carne asada, bean and cheese, and cheese.  They were all equally tasty, but I have to say my favorite was the plain cheese-- it was sooo good!  The Pupusas had a generous amount of filling and were perfectly browned on the outside, definitely better than any I've tried before.  One thing to note is for some reason everything is 55 cents more when you dine in, not sure why.
author: Anne A.

description:
So you think you have had good Pupusas? Think again! Vicky's in San Jose in no Match for this place. I am not super picky, but these were waaaaay better. I got one with Shrimp and Cheese (AMAZING!) and one with Prosciutto and Cheese ...(salty and melty). My GF got Spinach and Cheese (good but not as good as mine). The cabbage toppings and salsa really mixed well with it all. This is one place you HAVE to try.

Btw... if you are going to hit up all the other places nearby DO NOT trust google's walking directions, esp in the dark.
author: Oliver L.

description:
Tried 3 pupusas.  I destroyed all of them within minutes.   I had a Carne Asada, Chicken & Pork Pupusa.

Out of the 3.  The Chicken one was the Juiciest.  The pork one was not all that great.  Even my lady said that it stank.   

They only hooked it up with a lil bit of Cocido.  

My lady ordered a Combination plate with a Bean pupusa and Tamale & rice/beans.   The tamale was real mushy.  She was kind of hesitant, but ate it regardless.  Thougth it was ok.. Nothin too spectacular.

I'd come back.  The pupusas are not too greasy.  Its also cheaper to order out than to eat it there.   Not too far from a Salvadorean Bakery that we also hit up...   Not bad not bad..
author: Alex C.

description: I've been coming to this spot for 3 years...always a BIG treat.  THE BEST pupusas i've ever had, at the right price.  A perfect meal that doesn't break the bank.  Try the casamiento and chicken soup!!  Keep being awesome Balompie!!
author: Kyle H.

description:
what i ordered... pupusa with ground pork and cheese, pupusa with salvadorian vegetable and cheese

so far the best pupusa(s) i had ever tasted.............. freshly formed and perfectly cooked in front of you, tasty masa and not too much of and that folk's is a compliment, ground pork was just ground pork and a good thing it wasn't much, lot's of ooozing quesillo(it felt like i was eating a quesadilla) and on the side was a slushy yet tasty salsa to dip it into.

ambiance... ok(place need supply air, front door won't shut)
service... ok(nice and smiley)
cost...$(inexpensive to fair)
author: Gors P.

description:
Pupusa are the national dish of El Salvador.  I am Salvadorean so I am completely qualified to write this review.
This place does not deliver.  I had one chance to eat pupusas while I was in San Francisco.  Based on other reviews from Yelp, I tried Balompie.
We tried the fried yuca, too dry, topped with fried anchovies, that were not needed. 
The pupusas were ok, nothing special.  They are served  with curtido, which is pickled cabbage, and that was the best part I think.
The place was clean, but almost empty.  
The waitress wasn't very friendly and looked like she just wanted us to get out of there.
The best part about going here was the bus ride through the Mission.
author: Lila R.

description: Fried plantains and beans, or their specialty list of papusas, this place rocks my world. I ate there 2 weeks ago and I'm craving what I ate so bad I have to go back. Tonight. This place also gets a huge cred for taking me in and letting me use their bathroom when a nincompoop dropped a full Guinness beer from a window ledge 3 stories up, just across the street, completely drenching me in stout. When it comes to serving the food, they are quick, super nice and attentive in that familial way. The atmosphere is uber chill and homey - definitely a place I would go if I wanted to rock my laptop for a while and eat some good food. And did I mention the food is at a crazy low price? And their Negro Modelos are ice cold and super yum with their infamously delicious papusas. Hells yeah :D
author: Shelley D.

description:
3.5 but I will round up because I expect it to meet those four stars soon.

I have been eating at the OG Balompie on 18th Street for almost 20 years.  *gulp*   TWENTY YEARS!!!  Um, yeah I've been eating there since I was 2 years old.  Sure.  Yeah, that's it. . 2 years old. . . 

Anyway in the battle of pupusa greatness, to me, Balompie #1 has always come out on top over Panchita's, Zocolo and La Santaneca.    The fillings are always abundant and the dough is always tender and not greasy.  Their curtido is balanced and tasty.   Also, their caldo de pollo is my  I-am-so-sick-I-want-my-mommy therapy.

The only draw back of Balompie #1 is that it is ALWAYS crowded and the seats are packed in tight so you always feel cramped or rushed or infringed upon . . ..Balompie #3 is small but the tables are spaced well so that won't be a problem.  

The restaurant has only been open for three weeks and they are offering a fairly limited menu (compared to Balompie #1).  The star of the menu are the pupusas.  They have your usual suspects - cheese, revueltas, loroco, ayote, etc.  They also have "Specialty" pupusas. . .three with the stomach churning combo of fish, shrimp and cheese - not my cup of tea but three other ones - the Mejicana (sic) which is a mixture of ground pork, jalapenos, & cheese; the Italiana which is prosciutto and cheese and the Gringa which is seasoned ground beef and cheese.    They offer both the corn masa and the rice masa. . .my boyfriend likes the rice masa so he always gets those. . .I  much prefer corn masa.  He got the chicharron and queso (revueltas) in rice masa and I got the Mejicana in corn masa.  I also got an Italiana because, well, I had to. . . it sounded bizarre enough to work.  Being the fromage-o-phile that I am you must understand that what I am about to say goes against the very fiber of my being. . .the pupusas were good but not great because. . . .are you sitting down?. . . .there was TOO MUCH cheese in them.  I know.  Crazy talk.   But the balance was thrown by all that cheese.  I was piling on the curtido to balance out the richness of the cheese.  Also, the pupusas broke which isn't such a tragedy because the crispy cheese ooze is such a bonus but ALL of them were broken and mis-sized so their are a couple of consistency problems (see my pics).  But I did really like the mejicana - the combo was good and I liked the jalapenos and the nice kick they added.  So how about that Italiana?  It was GENIUS!  Seriously delicious. . .a good amount of prosciutto but not so much as to be overwhelmingly salty, cheese (not too much in this one) and fresh oregano leaves. . it worked.  My dream would be to have a couple of those with two fried eggs atop. . .it would be the breakfast of champions!  As stated earlier, Balompie #1 as the best curtido and that is true here as well. . also make sure to get some escabeche - theirs is so good!  We also had a side of casamiento which was a tad dry.   They are frying up fresh chips and they are delicious and the salsa, which is traditionally very low key - here it is actually quite good.  We also had some jamaica which was very, very good - not too sweet but not bitter or tart either - it went perfectly with our meal.  

I went again last night to get a quick bite and had the Gringa which was very good - this time not too much cheese but a little greasy from the ground beef.  But good.

I am excited to know that they will be open until midnight on Friday and Saturdays - you just never know when you might be overwhelmed by a desire for pupusas and now at least their is a fairly late night option out there.   

So why only three and a half stars?  Well . .. one thing is that they charge different prices for eating there or to go.  It's weird and off-putting.  Their menu is limited - I will update this review when they add a few more items - especially my beloved caldos and if you sit in the front two window tables at sundown you will hate your life. . .it's hot, bright and you have to eat wearing sunglasses - please my darling friends at Balompie #3 - get some shades for those windows!  PLEASE!
author: Lainie L.

description:
Walking in here on a Monday night around 8ish, there was only one empty table.  A couple of bar seats at the counter, but I was impressed!  We ate in, and were quickly attended to.  The place only got more crowded as the night went on.  Maybe it was the futbol (aka soccer) game that was on.  They had a TV, but I have to say I didn't notice who was playing.  All I know is, the place was packed on a Monday night, which is pretty awesome.

The hostess/waitress was super friendly and very helpful at answering our questions about the menu.  She spoke both English and Spanish well, which made communication easy for everyone.

My Jugo del Dia (Melon) tasted just like a fresh cantaloupe - delicious!  Chips and salsa were immediately placed on our table, and while the chips obviously came out of a Costco-type bag, the salsa was good.  Watery, but good flavor and just a tiny kick of spice.

I had the #14, which for $8.50 included 2 Pupusas con Arroz y Frijoles.  I chose to have the rice and beans Casamiento, which meant that they were mixed together and formed into a little mound.  It was SO good!  I chose a Carne Asada y Queso and a Gambas y Queso pupusa.  Both the steak and shrimp were good, especially when I put some salsa and the coleslaw stuff on it, but nothing fantastic.  They weren't greasy, but there was a little too much cheese for my taste, and I wished they had more flavor before I put the toppings on them.  The spicy vegetables served in a side dish were really good - especially the cauliflower.

It was a good meal and friendly service, but I'd probably try out a different pupuseria before coming back here again.

Oh, and to comment about the other review I saw about a hair in the food - all of the cooks were wearing hairnets the night I was there, so hopefully no more hairs in the food!  :-)
author: Lindsay B.

description:
This place just opened 3 weeks ago, and still is under the radar.  I've been passing by for a while looking at the sign, and wondering when they will open.  Well, they ARE!  They are only open from 4pm - 10:00 or 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday.  CLOSED on Monday and Tuesday.

This place is the complete opposite of the chaos of the one on 18th Street.  No rubbing of the elbows of the person next to you, and that's the only way this place lacks.  There are a a few tables, a counter, and even a few tables outside.  Why you would want to eat outside at the sometimes seedy corner of Richland and Mission is beyond me, but it that floats your boat, it's available to you.

I bought some pupusas to take home.  Four chicharron and cheese, 4 ground beef and cheese, and two bean and cheese.  The ground beef pupusas was a bit lighter than the chicharron, and not quite as tasty, but a refreshing change.  if I had to pick, it would be the pork.    You can also get them filled with prosciutto, and another filled with pork, jalapeno and cheese.

Other unique fillings are available such as FOUR different kind of vegetarian pupusas' for you vegetarians our there.  They are:  1) Zucchini, 2) Loroco, 3) Spinach, and 4) Super vegetarian, with spinach, mushroom, carrots and cheese. (WHAT?  No celery?!)  Well, 5 if you count the beans.

While this location lacks the multiple dishes as that on 18th Street, they will likely have more later.  One dish sounds very good ... Salpicon; chopped beef with mint, radishes, and onion with rice and beans.  You can get your Tamales, Pasteles, and Empanadas.  Prices are a bit cheaper for the pupusas if you have them to-go.  To go, they are $1.95 - $2.95 versus $2.50 - $3.50 if you eat inside.

Will it replace the venerable La Santaneca?  Maybe.  Very cute server with a winning smile.
author: Michael M.

description: Great pupusas, loads of choices of fillings. I like the classic ones the best!
author: Brian S.

description:
Best PUPUSAS! I loved the shrimp and fish while my roommate loved the Pork and Italian kind. We figured that we would have loved all of them if we had consumed it right when it came out from the kitchen. Eat it freshly hot and be amazed with the texture and taste. 

Semi Casual place. It's a really neat first date place or even a social encounter with group.
author: Hebert J.

description: I am El Salvadorean American and these pupusas are the best in the city!  If you want non-greasy traditional or non-traditional flavors, come here, they know what they are doing!
author: ada l.

description: Good pupusas! Shrimp pastel was a treat. Great service.
author: Lauren S.

description: Definitely one of the best places in town for pupusas!  There are other good spots in the Mission as well (Los Panchos), but I always find myself coming back here.  I haven't tried anything else here, but the huge selection of different pupusa flavors keeps it interesting!
author: Jeff M.

description: Yum. Comfort food. Freshly made pupusas. Football games on flat screens. And good juices, too.
author: Will H.

description:
Chicken Enchiladas FTW!!!  

This place is one block from my house, and now I'm sad I haven't gone their more.  We went with a group last night to grab some dinner to go.  I wasn't in the mood for a full meal, so I just got the enchiladas and a tamale off the appetizer menu.  For $5.75, you CAN NOT beat those enchiladas (you get two).  They were soooooo good and filling.  I didn't even need the tamale...but I ate it anyway; it wasn't as good as Tamale Lady's, but still tasty.  My friends got meals while were around $10 bucks, and they said they were great too.  

They good be a little quicker when it comes to making the food, but it's not like some wimpy taqueria where they're making everything to go, so it's okay to wait for delicious food.
author: Levi B.

description: i dont think ive ever had anything better, their beef soup is amazing made to order everything is made to order i love watching them make everything. me and my whole family go here all the time. i started bringing friends here to!! i love it!!!!!
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Balompie #3 (at the corner of Richland and Mission in the Bernal Heights-ish neighborhood) is really a great local joint.

The co-owner & manager, Jackie, is super-nice and makes sure everyone is well taken care of.  The one waiter that is there *all * the time (I need to remember his name next time) is also really friendly and often brings a large Regia to our table right away as he's learned we always get one.  They will often bring little "extras" to the table if we have a large order that will take a while...

Sitting at the counter, if you're there alone or with just one friend, is also great - the cooks are friendly and if you speak a wee bit of spanish they'll happily describe what's simmering on the stove or talk about where they live in Mexico, etc.

All-in-all a comfy atmospher and great (great great) pupusas.  This has become a standard on my take-out nights now since it is cheap, fast, and good.
author: J M.

description: The best pupusa variety in SF!  Must get the spinach one and lather it with salsa and curtido (lightly fermented cabbage slaw with chilies and vinegar) $2.50
author: Shannon Z.

description: Definitely a must go place when around the city. Food is delicious especially the pupusas they are the bomb. My favorite plates are the pan con pavo and pollo al limon. The restaurant is really clean and The staff is really friendly. Was there Thursday night and the waitress veronica was so nice and attentive service was great. Will be coming back again and again!!!
author: Manuel H.

description: Still loving Balompie 3. Beans & Cheese Pupusas! I could easily have them 2 or 3 nights a week - and don't tell anyone - but sometimes I actually do. .
author: Kelly S.

description:
this place is only a block away from my grandma's place, and i don't know why it took me so long to try it!

was also my first time trying pupusas, and they were great!  crispy outside and tasty inside.  lots of different ones to choose from, too. my mom and i shared 4 altogether, and had some to spare. a little too much cheese for my liking, though.

service was a little slow, but i think cause there was only one girl waitressing, though. 

can't wait to come again!
author: audrey s.

description: Balompie is clean, almost cutting edge in its ethnic yet hip presentation: open kitchen, wide screen sports oriented TV; semi boutique craft beer; locals and encroaching numbers of hipsters hang out. Overall a nice place for a good lunch/dinner. The food is very good and fairly priced. Hearty food which is for the most part, prepared in front of you. The staff is efficient  enough and most times offer a friendly smile. I like the pupusas, but again, hard to say the "best ever" since there are so many good pupusa places in SF. If anything, maybe they are just a tad skimpier with the queso than other places. But the mesa is fresh and cooked just right for my taste. Excellent pickled cabbage. Good place to take your hipster friend from Kansas who has never even had nor even thought of eating "Mexican" other than Taco Bell. "Oh my God, this is SO cool! Wait, I have to InstaGram these pooPahSaw things!"
author: Chad R.

description: Something about the word PUPUSA makes me crinch but then I think of the gooey, juicy and delicious things in the middle and i just melt. No pun intended. But in all seriousness these pupusas are the best I have ever had the pleasure of putting on my lips.
author: M R.

description: Best pupusas I've ever had and I lived in Central America. Ask for pupusas revueltas, they're not on the menu but they're pupusas with beans and pork inside. The casamiento (beans and rice) mix is also delicious. We are from out of state and Balompie is a must every time we're in California. Service has always been spectacular.
author: Chris L.

description: Um...why did it take me 28 years of life before I sampled a pupusa?? Balompie cafe is right near my house, thanks be to god, and I have now been properly educated in all things pupusa. Seriously, people...these little round pattys of delight are GOOD. Come check it out. My favorites are espinaca y queso and pollo y queso. Delish...
author: Shannon C.

description: Our usual papusa place was closed!  We were sad for a moment until we found Balompie Cafe 3 on Yelp. We now have a new favorite Papusa place!
author: mary s.

description: My first pupuseria, and last. Why try other places if this one is so great? The pupusa lady pat-pat-patting pupusas in the open kitchen is adorable. Everything is fresh and made to order. Friendly service. Clean and homey.
author: Presto G.

description: How have I never had a papusa before??? How did I not know there are actually restaurants called papusarias??? I guess I don't hang out in the Mission enough. I feel like such a bad foodie... but now a full and happy foodie. Balompie papusas were great! Of course, I don't have any previous papusa experience for comparison, but I still say they were great and apparently the place has awards to back me up. Great spot for lunch. Friendly service. Good food. Two papusas, beans and rice will have you set for the afternoon!
author: Caitlin H.

description: Just moved down the street and the pupusas here came highly recommended from several people. I was not disappointed! Had a deliciously filling meal for less than 5 bucks. I had a spinach and a chicharron pupusa and they were perfect together. My favorite part is watching them make them behind the counter. Lots of regulars making friendly conversation while waiting for their to-go orders, felt really homey.
author: Nicole A.

description: This place is amazing. Very friendly family atmosphere. I have say that the Salvadorean Enchiladas  is one of my favorite dishes in all of San Francisco. It is so simple but most of the time the best dishes come from the most basic fresh ingredients. I cant get enough, i just wish i lived closer to this phenomenal little joint.
author: Carl F.

description: I'm still new to Salvadoran cuisine, but Balompie Cafe #3 seems to offer the best by far. The pupusas are terrific and come in a variety of fillings- Chicharron y Queso is so far my fave. I've been to a couple other spots where the pupusas are tough and dry, Balompie's are moist and delicate. The Salvadoran Sampler is the right combo to order if you want a taste of "everything." This spot is a great new add to Bernal Heights and if you are new to Salvadoran- no worries, Balompie #3 has a nice open ambiance with friendly staff. Lucky for me, it's just around the corner...
author: Leroid D.

description: This is a pretty good place for Pupusas, and close to my place. Always good to stumble 3 blocks down for some nice, warm food. The lady who makes the Pupusas punches the dough with glee, and it makes me smile. I never thought a place this unassuming would be so good, but it's a solid place to go when you're hungry.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Balompie Cafe #3 is great! 

LIKES:
love their pupusas and I can eat it for breakfast, lunch AND dinner...SERIOUSLY! Ask my husband! Their side of pickled vegetables is tasty and their salsa is excellent! 

Place is clean, food is fresh and made-to-order! 

Service is great and friendly! 

DISLIKES:
dine-in fee
hard-to-find parking

I'll be back soon!
author: Jennifer C.

description: I must say this place is very good. I have tried several things on the menu but must say those enchiladas are off the hook.
